messageBody:
At 05:50 PM 9/12/2002 -0600, you wrote:
>Quoth Chappell, Simon P:
> [...]
> > I think that, for me, it's partly a matter of "rightness" and the
> > rest is reporting. The "rightness" is that it is the Right Thing
> > To Do(tm) to throw a IAE when receiving junk parameters. [...]
>
>*chuckle* I'll so stipulate, though I notice that the existing
>Java API doesn't do so in all cases. (I don't mean to refer only
>to its throwing NullPtrExc when arguments are unexpectedly null as
>others have noted, but also, eg., to its throwing
>IndexOutOfBoundsExc from String.charAt(), and ArithmeticExc from
>BigInteger.divide().)

An in fact that is by design. From the book "Effective Java" by Joshua
Bloch, pg. 176:

"Arguably, all erroneous method invocations boil down to an illegal
argument or illegal state, but other exceptions are standardly used for
certain kings of illegal arguments and states. If a claller passes null in
some parameeter for which null values are prohibited, convention dictates
that NullPointExcpetion be thrown rather than IllegalArgumentException.
Similarly if a caller passes an out-of-range value in a parameter
representing an index into a sequence, IndexOutOfBoundsException should be
thrown rather than IllegalArgumentException."

Thus the use of NullPointerException is a standard convention at Sun. Note
that the book also states that such a usage should be documented in the API
contract.

-Kathy
